Award.AwardTitle: Achieving Community College Excellence for Scholarship Success (ACCESS)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The ACCESS (Achieving Community College Excellence for Scholarship Success) program is supporting scholarships for academically talented, financially needy students and enabling them to enter the workforce following completion of an associate degree in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) disciplines. Goals include improving educational opportunities for students, increasing retention of scholarship students to degree achievement, improving student support programs for scholarship participants, and increasing the numbers of well-educated and skilled employees in technical areas of national need.

Intellectual Merit: Scholarships are being awarded to 25 students each semester in STEM disciplines. The goals are (a) 75% of ACCESS Scholars maintain or exceed a 2.6 grade point average (GPA); (b) 70% of ACCESS Scholars persist until associate degree achievement; and (c) 100% of students are provided transfer or job placement assistance.

Broader Impact: As the sole accredited provider of postsecondary education in a large service area, the mission of the college is to provide accessible higher education opportunities to community residents. By offering scholarships to academically talented, financially needy students majoring in STEM disciplines, the college is meeting the needs of both the agricultural industries in the district and students. Over 70% of the students attending the college are first-generation who have had little exposure to scientific career opportunities. About 40% of the students are Hispanic and a great number of these students come from families where the parents are migrant workers or field laborers. Recruitment of these students into scientific careers not only impacts their future, but it also increases the scientific awareness of friends and family members in their communities. The broader impact resulting from improved STEM education and STEM scholarships conveys the message that exciting, lucrative careers exist in the sciences and that agricultural careers are not limited to field work.

Institution.Name: West Hills Community College
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: WEST HILLS COMMUNITY COLLEGE DISTRICT FINANCING CORPORATION

POR.DRECONTENT:
West Hills College Lemoore, a Hispanic Serving Institution, is a small, rural community college located in California's agriculturally dominated San Joaquin Valley. The majority of students attending WHC Lemoore are first-generation (70%) and minority (77%), who have had little exposure to scientific career opportunities. The ACCESS (Achieving Community College Excellence for Scholarship Success) program awarded scholarships to academically talented financially needy STEM students, enabling them to transfer to a four-year university or to enter the workforce following completion of an Associate's degree in science, technology, engineering and math disciplines.

A great number of the WHC Lemoore ACCESS Scholars come from families where the parents are involved in the agriculture industry, some as migrant workers or field laborers.  Recruitment of these students into scientific careers not only impacted the student's future, but it also increased the scientific awareness of friends and family members in their communities.  We observed this impact first-hand, as over the course of the grant award performance period we had numerous siblings and spouses follow their family member to West Hills College Lemoore and participate in the NSF S-STEM ACCESS Scholars program.  The broader impact resulting from improved STEM education and STEM scholarships conveyed the message that exciting, lucrative careers exist in the sciences -- and that agricultural careers are not limited to field work.

Throughout the performance period of the NSF S-STEM ACCESS Scholars program, WHC Lemoore awarded 240 scholarships.  In addition to providing financial support through the scholarships, student access to cultural and social capital increased by engaging students with STEM faculty and with industry professionals through field trips which included visits to the Jet Propulsion Lab at Cal Tech in Pasadena, CA, the Googleplex at Mountain View, CA, and Pixar Studios in Emeryville CA. The WHC Lemoore NSF S-STEM ACCESS Scholars program awarded scholarships to 93 unduplicated students; 66.5% were minority students while 33.5% self-identified as Caucasian. Of the S-STEM ACCESS Scholars receiving financial support for at least one semester, 46% were female and 54% were male. Student attitudinal and self-efficacy surveys from each program year determined that the WHC Lemoore NSF S-STEM ACCESS Scholars overwhelmingly believed the program was instrumental to their academic success.


Last Modified: 10/17/2017
Modified by: Brian Abela
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: West Hills College Lemoore, a Hispanic Serving Institution, is a small, rural community college located in California's agriculturally dominated San Joaquin Valley. The majority of students attending WHC Lemoore are first-generation (70%) and minority (77%), who have had little exposure to scientific career opportunities. The ACCESS (Achieving Community College Excellence for Scholarship Success) program awarded scholarships to academically talented financially needy STEM students, enabling them to transfer to a four-year university or to enter the workforce following completion of an Associate's degree in science, technology, engineering and math disciplines. A great number of the WHC Lemoore ACCESS Scholars come from families where the parents are involved in the agriculture industry, some as migrant workers or field laborers. Recruitment of these students into scientific careers not only impacted the student's future, but it also increased the scientific awareness of friends and family members in their communities. We observed this impact first-hand, as over the course of the grant award performance period we had numerous siblings and spouses follow their family member to West Hills College Lemoore and participate in the NSF S-STEM ACCESS Scholars program. The broader impact resulting from improved STEM education and STEM scholarships conveyed the message that exciting, lucrative careers exist in the sciences -- and that agricultural careers are not limited to field work. Throughout the performance period of the NSF S-STEM ACCESS Scholars program, WHC Lemoore awarded 240 scholarships. In addition to providing financial support through the scholarships, student access to cultural and social capital increased by engaging students with STEM faculty and with industry professionals through field trips which included visits to the Jet Propulsion Lab at Cal Tech in Pasadena, CA, the Googleplex at Mountain View, CA, and Pixar Studios in Emeryville CA. The WHC Lemoore NSF S-STEM ACCESS Scholars program awarded scholarships to 93 unduplicated students; 66.5% were minority students while 33.5% self-identified as Caucasian. Of the S-STEM ACCESS Scholars receiving financial support for at least one semester, 46% were female and 54% were male. Student attitudinal and self-efficacy surveys from each program year determined that the WHC Lemoore NSF S-STEM ACCESS Scholars overwhelmingly believed the program was instrumental to their academic success.
